citations.narrative:
There were four or more missing ceiling tiles above the primary enclosure of two spider monkeys that the facility
representative reported had been pulled down by the spider monkeys. There were exposed electrical wires and what
appeared to be a hanging smoke detector within reach of the spider monkeys. An intact ceiling tile contained an electrical
box with capped wires hanging down that the spider monkeys would be able to reach through the top of their primary
enclosure.
Failure to maintain structurally sound housing facilities for nonhuman primates that protect them from injury, such as
having electrical cords within reach, may result in adverse events such as electrocution or strangulation.
Exhibitors must design and construct housing facilities that are structurally sound for the species of nonhuman primates
housed and protect them from injury.
To be Corrected by: March 28th, 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Shawna Abrams, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.75(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
There were four or more missing ceiling tiles above the primary enclosure of two spider monkeys that the facility 
representative reported had been pulled down by the spider monkeys. There were exposed electrical wires and what 
appeared to be a hanging smoke detector within reach of the spider monkeys. An intact ceiling tile contained an electrical 
box with capped wires hanging down that the spider monkeys would be able to reach through the top of their primary 
enclosure.  
Failure to maintain structurally sound housing facilities for nonhuman primates that protect them from injury, such as 
having electrical cords within reach, may result in adverse events such as electrocution or strangulation.  
Exhibitors must design and construct housing facilities that are structurally sound for the species of nonhuman primates 
housed and protect them from injury. 
To be Corrected by: March 28th, 2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Shawna Abrams, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
